article_title: Study shows wide variance in health care costs, even in the same city
article_text:
Study shows wide variance in health care costs, even in the same city Study finds wide variations in prices for procedures in Houston and across U.S.; some differences are 'disturbing'

Photo: Mayra Beltran, Staff A patient gets a CT scan done in the emergency room at Memorial... While Houston's health care costs are generally on par with or even sometimes lower than those in other major cities, there continues to be a wide disparity in what providers charge for the exact same procedure or exam, a new national study shows.

To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to HoustonChronicle.com. Houston Chronicle subscribers have FREE access to all premium digital products.

article_metadata.description: While Houston's health care costs are generally on par with or even sometimes lower than those in other major cities, there continues to be a wide disparity in what providers charge for the exact same procedure or exam, a new national study shows.  [...] both still cost less than last year and are ranked in the middle range of pricing compared to the rest of the nation, the second annual Castlight Health Costliest Cities Index shows.  Some of the price differences for the same procedures in the same cities are huge - and troubling, Kristin Torres Mowat, vice president of strategic alliances at the San Francisco-based health care technology company, said in an interview Tuesday.  The study added four common women's health services for the 2015 study: mammograms, obstetrician-gynecologist follow-up visits, preventative gynecological exams and human papilloma virus screening.  Other Houston findings include: the price of a first-time physical by a primary-care provider ranges from $95 to $273; a cholesterol test ranges from $18 to $387; a follow-up visit to an obstetrician-gynecologist ranges from $59 to $122; and a human papilloma virus test ranges from $32 to $441.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam

Some of the price differences for the same procedures in the same cities are huge - and troubling, Kristin Torres Mowat, vice president of strategic alliances at the San Francisco-based health care technology company, said in an interview Tuesday.
